channel.title: Combined Politepol Feed
channel.description: Merged feed from multiple Politepol sources

item.title: As Trump & al-Sharaa meet, how Syria is entering a new era of diplomacy with the US
'Huge explosion, shops trembled’: How the Delhi car blast unfolded
The many scandals that have marred BBC's reputation in recent years
Is Delhi car explosion a suicide bombing? The Pulwama link and what probe reveals so far
History Today: How World War I ended after pact was signed in rail carriage
Sitamarhi, Purnia & more… Key seats to watch out for in Phase 2 of Bihar elections
India’s exit from Ayni base in Tajikistan reflects a reorientation of its strategic choices
item.description: India’s withdrawal from Ayni, which started in 2022, will likely re-energise its pursuit of new military facilities in the Indian Ocean—the next arena of strategic contest and competition

item.title: Dear ‘Economist’, India's stability is not accidental, but a model of economic governance
item.description: India’s contemporary equilibrium cannot be explained through macroeconomic aggregates alone, it must be understood as a multidimensional construct emerging from a coherent political economy framework that integrates security, fiscal policy, welfare architecture, institutional reform, and foreign policy

item.title: Small in size, big in tech and influence: How Taiwan punches above its weight in Apec
item.description: In a region facing structural shifts—digital transformation, green transition, supply-chain re-engineering—Taiwan’s quiet but strategic engagement via Apec offers lessons in how mid-sized economies can exert influence, build partnerships and contribute to regional public goods

item.title: A new nuclear race could begin as Trump and Putin revive Cold War shadows
item.description: At most at this point the posturing between the US and Russia can be seen as a new era of nuclear competition

item.title: How Pakistan’s 27th amendment will turn a ‘failed marshal’ into a dictator
item.description: No wonder PTI leader Imran Khan called Asim Munir the ‘most oppressive dictator in Pakistan’s history’

item.title: Beyond clamour of polls and silence of migration seeps the forgotten glory of Darbhanga Raj
item.description: At the time of Independence, Darbhanga was one of the subcontinent’s most prosperous and better-managed administrative units, whose rise and fall form an important chapter of India’s history
